H0.text: Electrons are the particles partially lost by hydrogen when it undergoes oxidation.

H1.text: Density is the partial loss that the hydrogen undergoes when it is oxidized.

H2.text: Protons are what hydrogen partially loses during oxidation.

H3.text: Ions are what the hydrogen partially loses when it is oxidized.

A4.text: In the reaction between hydrogen and fluorine, hydrogen is converted to protons (H+).

A5.text: Oxidation is the loss of electrons or an increase in the oxidation state.

A6.text: In the reaction between hydrogen and fluorine, hydrogen is converted to protons (H+) and releases electrons.

A8.text: These valence electrons also facilitate all types of chemical reactions by being transferred or shared between atoms.

A9.text: The outermost or valence electrons are the least tightly bound and are responsible for the formation of chemical bonds between atoms to create molecules and crystals.
